WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 405 July 1980 THE EFFECTS OF EDUCATION ON HEALTH A Background Study for World Development Report, 1980 This paper investigates, from three overlapping perspectives, the effects of education on health. The determinants of mortality are receiving increasing scrutiny because the rate of mortality reduction in the developing world appears to have slowed at levels of life expectancy below those thought attainable only a few years ago. The first perspective employed in this paper is a broad assessment of the socioeconomic determinants of mortality on a cross-national basis; using aggregate data, this paper contains a review and a reanalysis of the large body of literature that has accumulated on international differences in mortality and life expectancy. The second perspective sharpens the focus by concentrating on the relationship between education and mortality since the cross-national evidence suggests that education, or its proxy literacy, is the most important variable involved. A theoretical model of the relationship between parental education and child health is developed and used to describe how aggregate and individual data may give different estimates of the relationship. The third perspective employed reviews and reanalyzes the evidence at the subnational level. Individual evidence is reviewed on the relationship between parental education and both child nutrition and child mortality. This evidence is then compared with aggregate data to test the implications of the model. Prepared by: Susan H. Cochrane Donald J.  I. INTRODUCTION A. Purpose of the Paper This paper investigates, from three overlapping perspectives, the effects of education on health. The quality of life in the developing world rests ultimately on the basic facts of mortality rates and the human potential preserved or actualized by their reduction. Yet the rate of mortality reduction in the countries of the developing world appears to have slowed at levels of life expectancy below those thought attainable only a few years ago. In the attempt to identify the causes of this slowdown, the determinants of mortality are receiving increased scrutiny. The first perspective employed in this paper is, therefore, a broad one: that of an assessment of socioeconomic determinants of mortality on a crossnational basis. It presents a review of, and, where appropriate, a reanalysis to acquire new insights into, the findings of a large body of liter- ature that has accumulated on the determinates of mortality, using data on national differences in mortality, socioeconomic development and, where possible, provision of medical services. The second perspective employed is to sharpen the focus of the study by concentrating on one aspect of the relationship between education and mortality, since the cross-national evidence suggests that education, or its proxy, literacy, seems to be the most important variable involved. A theoretical model of the relationship between parental education and child health is developed and used to describe how aggregate and individual data may give different estimates of the relationship. The third perspective employed in the study, emerging from the second, is one that further sharpens the focus by concentrating on a review of evidence at the individual level, specifically, intracountry evidence on parental education and its association with child health. In sum: national and equally substantial individual evidence, taken together, help elucidate the significance of the effects of parental education on child health; this association, as clarified by careful and detailed analysis employing standard statistical techniques, is of no small concern to the theory and practice of poverty-reducing development in the 1980s and beyond. B. Organization of the Paper Reflecting the three perspectives mentioned above, the remainder of the paper is divided into three chapters. The first of these, Chapter II, investigates the socioeconomic determinants of mortality, using cross-national evidence. After a brief introduction, Chapter II is made up of five main sections and a brief conclusion. The first section introduces and assesses the use of cross-national regression and correlation analysis. Following this review of aggregate data the analysis moves on to an assessment of the cross- national evidence regarding life expectancy and per capita income. The next section offers a comparative analysis of the relation between income and life expectancy through a reanalysis of the data from earlier findings. The fourth section reviews the evidence associating income distribution , life expectancy, and mortality, using bivariate and multivariate analysis and summarizing various findings.
 -2- Chapter III presents an attempt at modeling the effect of education on health. It first reviews the general relationship of education and health, then assesses broad aspects of the effects of the former on the latter. It next addresses the pertinent questions: "Whose education? Whose health?" concluding that the clearest analysis is possible for parental education and child health. A model of household production of health is then presented. Familiar supply and demand concepts are then used to facilitate interpretation, and special cases are then analyzed. The effects on the model of incorporating other determinants of health are then addressed, as are the challenges presented by omitted exogenous variables in four types of sample. The problem of the inclusion of "inappropriate" variables is then addressed, and the chapter concludes by assessing the simultaneous determination of education and health for the popu- lation as a whole. Chapter IV, in reviewing the intracountry evidence relating parental education and child health, offers an overall introduction and then analyzes parental education and the nutritional status of children; the microlevel data on parental education and child mortality, including a multivariate analysis of the effect of education; and an analysis of aggregation that includes both intracountry aggregate multivariate determinants of child mortality and the effect of aggregate characteristics on the individual education-child mortality relationship. Chapter IV ends with a concluding review which sets the results of the analysis within the broader framework of the paper. Because of the specific focus of each of the three main chapters, separate references .to the literature surveyed and analyzed, and to other relevant studies, will be found at the end of each of the chapters. Tabular presentations are used throughout as a means to summarizing the main-findings of the various statistical analyses used in the paper.

Introduction The rate of reduction of mortality in the countries of the developing world seems to have slowed at levels of life expectancy below what was thought achievable only a few years ago (Gwatkins, 1979).** To identify the causes of this slowdown, the determinants of mortality are being studied with renewed interest. The major question appears to be the extent to which such reductions have been, and will continue to be, limited by income and living standards and to what extent by medical technology and health delivery systems. Samuel Preston and Robert Gardner have stated that: "given motiva- tion, the level of mortality in a population must be a product of two fac- tors: the level of knowledge regarding ways to combat diseases, and the means available for implementing that knowledge. These factors operate at both the individual and the societal level." (Preston and Gardner, 1976, p. 2.) But they go on to state that, given the externalities involved in mortality transmission, at an aggregate level one must also add as a factor the "ability of a group to organize available resources to achieve commonly valued goals. " Much of the debate about past and potential reductions in mortality can be placed within this framework. A large body of literature has accumulated on the determinants of mortality on the national level using aggregate data; the major conclusions of this work will now be reviewed, and, whenever possible, the data will be reanalyzed to provide new insights. B. The Aggregate Analysis Two types of analysis have been used to explain the relative importance of economic resources and medical technology in determining mortality levels and changes at the aggregate level. The method most familiar to economists is bivariate or multivariate regression analysis. A second technique, used by demographers, is the analysis of changes in cause of death combined with inform- ation about how such diseases have been brought under control.  -4- Before reviewing the cross-national studies of the determinants of mortality it is necessary to give two warnings. First, there is very little specific theory on the socioeconomic determinants of mortality, as opposed to biological theories about causes of death. Second, the data on life expectancy or age-adjusted mortality are not routinely generated by vital registration systems in developing countries. Much of the analysis of cross-national data is therefore restricted to countries which are atypical of the world as a whole, particularly for earlier points in time. In reviewing such studies, it is thus necessary to pay close attention to the countries included in the sample, to determine if sample bias affects the results. The lack of theory pertaining to the socioeconomic determinants of mortality manifests itself in the literature by a lack of agreement on what variables should be included in the analysis, and what mathematical specification should be used in empirical estimation. Per capita income is the most widely discussed socioeconomic determinant of mortality, primarily because it is considered a summary of the ability of an economy to meet the needs of its citizens. We shall accordingly begin our analysis by examining those bivariate studies which examine the relationship between a country's life expectancy or mortality and per capita income. The questions that have been raised at the policy level about the relationship between mortality or life expectancy and income are often fairly cloudy and difficult to test empirically. Most of the concern seems to center around whether it is possible to achieve further reductions in mortality in the developing countries through "cheap" health interventions, or whether mortality can only be reduced by increasing standards of living. Earlier analysis of the British experience in the 19th century (McKeown, Brown and Record, 1972) and the Latin American experience prior to the 1930s (Arriaga and Davis, 1965) showed that mortality decline was closely related to improvements in living standards rather than medical breakthroughs. From the 1930s to the 1960s, however, it was claimed mortality reduction were largely independent of increases in living standards (Arriaga and Davis, 1965). The new concern 'centers around the issue of whether we are in fact entering an age when medical technology can do little to reduce mortality if living standards do not improve.' Much of the analysis to date, although quite valuable, has however been based on rather impression- istic discussions of changes in mortality from specific causes. Further, the data base is inadequate in many areas and in any event there is a lack of vigorous methodology. This is not to imply that mortality reductions can in fact continue without improvements in living standards, but rather that we do not as yet know enough about the relationship between living standards and mortality to make firm statements. To learn more, we need to phrase our questions in an empirically verifiable form. Using aggregate data we can ask about the relationship between mortality and income in two basic ways. First, we can ask how closely have income and mortality been related in various periods, and whether this has changed over time. This initial question can itself be rephrased in two ways: (1) At any point in time how much of the variation in mortality or life expectancy is "explained" by variations in per capita income, and has the proportion of variation changed over time? (This is a question of
 -5- goodness-of-fit.) (2) At any point in time how much of an increase in life-expectancy is associated with a given increase in income, and has this changed over time? (This is a question of the slope or elasticity of life expectancy with respect to income.) These two formulations of the first question are often confused. The second question is: How much of the change over time in mortality or life expectancy is related to income? "Related to income" is generally interpreted to mean "related to changes in income," but it is possible that levels of income in one period might be responsible for changes in mortality over a subsequent period. Some formulations of the question on the relationship between income and mortality seem to ask whether this dynamic relationship has changed over time. While the theory of the relationship between income and mortality at any point in time is underdeveloped, the theory of how that relationship shifts over time is unfortunately nonexistent. In the following review we shall therefore simply analyze the existing empirical studies to determine what insights they give on these questions, and then reanalyze some of the data to elucidate fresh insights. C. Life Expectancy and Per Capita Income: The Evidence The specification of the functions to be reviewed here varies widely. The only consensus is that: (1) income is positively related to life expectancy (i.e. negatively related to mortality); and (2) there is an upper limit on life expectancy (or a lower limit on mortality) above which (below which) increases in income will have no effect. 1/ Beyond these basic restrictions, there has been considerable variation in the functional relationship assumed in the studies reviewed. First, whenever changes over time are calculated they are of necessity restricted to those data sets in which data are available at both periods, and thus to the smaller data set which is usually the one in the earlier time period. Our earlier analysis showed that this can introduce some change in the results. Secondly, the length of the periods involved are quite different. A-comparison of the role of income changes (or exogenous factors) in mortality declines between 1930 and 1963 or even 1940 and 1963 and between mortality changes in 1963 and 1970 can be quite misleading unless we recognize that technology had a much longer time to operate and that one must not expect exogenous changes to be as great in a 7 year period as in a 33 ora 23 year period. A third, and related, point would seem to be that the shorter the time period, the less the change resulting from exogenous factors (a function of random breakthough in medicine) and the more it is a function of the implementation in a country of known technology, which is in itself a function of its income level. With these caveats in mind we shall now examine the data in Table 2-2. The double logged relationship between changes in life expectancy and changes in income are very startling. The change in life expectancy is negatively related to changes in income, and in most cases these coeffi- cients are significant. If, however, we add the initial level of income we get a much clearer picture. It is not the change or increase in income per se which is negatively related to life expectancy, but the initial level of income. One finds that changes in income are positively related to changes in life expectancy, but that the coefficients of income changes are not significant. Interpreting this result is not too difficult if one recalls both the close relationship between income and life expectancy and the diminishing returns to increases in income at higher levels of income on life expectancy. One would therefore expect that it is the initially higher level of life expectancy in high income countries that might cause this perverse result. Given this information, it seems more appropriate to specify the relationship in such a way as to include the initial level of life expectancy in the equation explaining changes in life expectancy. Parental Education and Child Mortality: The Micro Evidence A considerable amount of research is now underway on the socio- economic determinants of mortality in developing countries, as evidenced by the Mexico City conference in the summer of 1979. We shall now review two kinds of evidence on the relationship between child mortality and parental education. First, we shall examine the evidence from a broad range of surveys in developing countries which cross-tabulate child survival by mother's level of education. This allows us to estimate the gross relation- ship. There is evidence of this kind from 33 developing countries. Secondly, we shall look at the much smaller number of studies which use micro data in the multivariate analysis of child mortality. 1. Bivariate Relationship between Parental Education and Child Mortality There are three ways of estimating child mortality. The first is to calculate the proportion of children surviving to mothers of different educational levels. To be meaningful, these data should be calculated separately for women of different age groups to control for the period of exposure to death (that is, older women have older children which have had a longer period in which to risk dying) and for the fact that mortality has been changing over time. A second method is to use indirect estimates of child mortality which allow one to calculate the probability that a child will die by a given age, say age two. This controls for the child age effect, but not the effect of changes in mortality over time. The third method is to look at detailed birth histories and calculate the proportion of children who die by age one, two, five, etc. This last technique requires that the women report the timing of past events very accurately, and is therefore not a useful technique for many samples. The evidence on the indirect estimation will be reviewed first, and then the other kinds of evidence. Suspecting that one month's income may be a poor measure of permanent income, he estimates equations explaining the log of monthly income by education, experience (age-education) and experience squared, and by dummy variables representing place of residence (23 departments for males; 4 or 5 regions for females). In rural areas, the wife's income is usually significant and the husband's not, while for education the situation is reversed -- only husband's education is consistently significant. In urban areas,-husband's income and education are only occasionally significant, while wife's income and education are usually highly significant. The coefficient on schooling is, however, with one exception, positive. Schultz interprets this finding as follows: wife's education increases the wife's income, which reduces child mortality, but also increases the wife's time outside the home, which increases child mortality (in this case, the increase is enough to offset about half the reduction due to higher income), but the overall net effect of education is still negative. The possibility of this result is recognized in the theoretical structure outlined in Chapter III, but it rarely seems to arise with this strength and consistency in the other empirical work reviewed. One possibility is that the dummy variables for place of residence, which play a large part in imputed income, are in fact picking up not only geographical variation in labor markets, as Schultz intends, but also variation in public health services, sanitation, and the like. Aggregate Relationships Study of the effects of parental education on child health at the household level must be the starting point for understanding how education might operate to reduce mortality. Clearly, however, we have only begun to quanitfy the relationship and have not yet been able to find factors that might explain either the consistency of results or their variation. Given the scarcity of existing household studies, there is a real temptation to generalize about education's effect from more generally available aggregate studies, such as the cross-national studies reviewed in Chapter II.  -91- These results are unsurprising and intuitively appealing, but given the small number of countries involved and the imprecise measurements used, one wonders how robust the results are. In particular, the failure of life expectancy-per se or illiteracy rates or income to affect the differentials is somewhat surprising. The analysis can be expanded by repeating the analysis for the countries included in Table 4-7. The results of this analysis are shown in items 3 and 4 of Table 4-11. Only the results for women aged 30-34 are reported, because those for younger women were not generally significant. For women aged 30-34 the regressions restricted to the smaller sample of significant slopes show greater explanatory power. Therefore, the results in items 3 and 4 report two sets of regressions. Those with the restricted sample are shown in brackets. The results for the proportion of children dying for women aged 30-34 are not very interesting when the entire sample is used. In all cases the only significant variable is either life expectancy or the intercept from Table 4-7. The interpretations of these results are always the same, i.e., the higher the mortality (the lower the life expectancy) the greater the effect of education on child mortality. This finding is consistent with the findings in items l(b) and 2(b) of Table 4-11, and the results of aggregate studies shown in Figure 1. When the sample is restricted to those countries where the bivariate analysis showed significant relationship between education and mortality, the results are more interesting: (1) higher levels of illiteracy result in larger effects of education on child mortality; (2) greater government expend- itures on health per capita result in less of an effect of education on mortality; (3) in these equations life expectancy and the intercept do not behave in the same way, life expectancy coefficients are less significant than those for the intercept values and are perverse, but the intercept values show that the higher mortality the greater the effect of education on mortality.
 -92- Conclusion This analysis has indicated that maternal education is closely related to child health whether measured by nutritional status or infant and child mortality. The evidence on the significance of the relationship is unequivocal. The magnitude is more difficult to determine. Bivariate analysis of infant and child mortality indicates that on the average an additional year of schooling for a mother results in a reduction of 9 per 1,000 in the mortality of her offspring. Multivariate analysis suggests that part of this effect results from the fact that more educated women tend to be married to more educated men., The best estimate is that the effect of husband's education is about one half the effect of the wife's. Accordingly, of the reduction of 9 per 1,000, approximately 3 per 1,000 is the result of the wife's own education, and 3 per 1,000 the result of her husband's education. The aggregate analysis within countries suggests that the estimates of education's relationship with infant and child mortality obtained by using aggregate data overstate the true effect because the education of an area tends to be associated with other factors such as access to health care, etc., which also result in improved health. This analysis and the analysis of the factors associated with country differences in the strength of the relationship between maternal education and child mortality suggests that education's effect is greater in areas of high mortality. The latter analysis also indicates that children's life chances can be equalized across educational groups to some extent by higher government health expenditures. The exact mechanism through which education acts to affect child health is unclear. Better nutrition among the children of the more educated has been well-documented here, and this would lead to improved survival. But it is unclear to what extent these effects result from improved knowledge directly resulting from education or.from higher income; the analysis does, however, suggest that income differences cannot explain all the effect, or perhaps even as much as half.

doc.repnme: The effects of education on health
doc.abstracts: This paper investigates the effects of education on health. The determinants of mortality are receiving increasing scrutiny because the rate of mortality reduction in the developing world appears to have slowed at levels of life expectancy below those thought attainable only a few years ago. The first perspective employed in this paper is a broad assessment of the socioeconomic determinants of mortality on a cross-national basis; using aggregate data, this paper contains a review and a reanalysis of the large body of literature that has accumulated on international differences in mortality and life expectancy. The second perspective sharpens the focus by concentrating on the relationship between education and mortality since the cross-national evidence suggests that education, or its proxy literacy, is the most important variable involved. A theoretical model of the relationship between parental education and child health is developed and used to describe how aggregate and individual data may give different estimates of the relationship. The third perspective employed reviews and reanalyzes the evidence at the subnational level. Individual evidence is reviewed on the relationship between parental education and both child nutrition and child mortality.
